title: Ticket #3310: STARTER_RLIMIT_AS not enforced for PreCmd and PostCmd
description:
(reproduced w/o modification from https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=874526) 

 Bert DeKnuydt 2012-11-08 06:34:52 EST

Description of problem:

The variable STARTER_RLIMIT_AS is enforced for the normal job, but
not for pre- and post-scripts, as specified through optional +PreCmd
resp. +PostCmd lines in the job description file.

This gives an easy way for the 'less cooperative' user to circumvent
limits.

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):

condor-7.9.1-0.1.fc17.2

How reproducible:

Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Set e.g. STARTER_RLIMIT_AS = 1024
2. Have a 'ulimit -a' in a +PreCmd script
3. Have a 'ulimit -a' in the job itself
4. Run the lot.

Actual results:

PreScript output: (only relevant part)

virtual memory          (kbytes, -v) unlimited

Joblog output:

virtual memory          (kbytes, -v) 1024000

Expected results:

I'd expect limits enforced to both Pre-script, job and Post-script.
Otherwise, an inventive user just runs the real job in an unlimited
pre-script, and has a limited, but empty job script.

Additional info:

Actually, it's worse than that: common practice is to tame users using
the USER_JOB_WRAPPER script, to put e.g. max. number of processes there,
or clever things with cpuset.  However, USER_JOB_WRAPPER is not invoked
for neither the Pre- and Post- scripts.  So here too, a creative user can
escape our magic ...
